ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I have renewed my reading knowledge of Japanese thanks to the intensive reading.
I learned so much about modern Japanese literature. I enjoyed this class greatly and felt like many of the books were classics. The readings were not too long but very intriguing.
Exposure to an overview of recent Japanese literature, including some major contemporary figures. I also strengthened my skills in close reading and literary analysis.
Japanese contemporary literature
In depth reading, analysis, and discussion of modern Japanese literature
Some contemporary Japanese literature and history, how the popularity of some specific fiction works reflect the Japanese society/the global audience, etc.

This class was great as a survey of post-1970's Japanese Lit (which is all very surreal, existential, and fun). You'll read a great syllabus (which is valuable in and of itself) and have a pretty casual (but interesting) discussion.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the reading might be slightly too heavy because I have taken another course in similar format and we read 9 novels (sometimes parts of a novel) for the whole semester. And a twenty minute lecture in the beginning of every class would be very nice. And perhaps we could learn something about the general information about the background, author, etc.
The essay could've been a little more collaborative, but as this isn't a writing class it made sense. I thought it ran very smoothly with COVID.

Strengths: the syllabus and course readings were fantastic, really interesting and engaging. The professor was also very engaged and his input made the class more engaging and insightful. There were no weaknesses.

Strengths: the selected works were quite informative, distinct with individual style and telling about its time period. It was easy to keep engaged because the readings were mostly fiction, and mostly pretty interesting. I learned a lot from the prof and my peers as well.  

Weaknesses: I wish there were more guided questions to help structure the discussions in class (because its easy to deviate with spontaneous discussion) and maybe a bit of lecture each time regarding the authors background & societal background for the work.

The novels were varied, reasonable length for a once-per-week class, and generally incredibly captivating. Some moments class discussions lagged, but I would fault Zoom for that, not anything regarding the class. I would've liked more direction regarding the final paper.

Some books on the reading list are interesting; the final paper gives a pretty high degree of freedom, and I was able to close-read a book beyond the course reading list and delve deep into a specific period of Japan's history.

There're some pop fictions on the reading list that definitely don't deserve an entire 2-hr meeting to discuss. Class discussion sometimes go off-topic. Kinda expected Prof. to guide the conversations a bit more.

Discussions weren't too heavily monitored or directed but I think that's a good thing. It let us freely focus on different points of the novels and explore the book thematically rather than chronologically.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think Zoom makes it harder to engage with the class because people cannot talk at the same time and have an active discussion and we are resolved to listening to prolonged arguments that are actually less than what they seem.
This was probably the best-run class with COVID that I had. Many people engaged and I had a good time.

The 10-min breakout rooms every day before class starts are effective. It allows me to understand where my interpretation of the book lies on the spectrum of the entire class's understanding. It also prepares me to organize my thoughts and contribute to the class discussion.

I think it's really hard to host a discussion seminar over Zoom. Our section was pretty quiet most days and Professor Goddard never tried to cold call us or anything (which was nice). I'm not sure how that might be fixed... probably just a result of circumstances.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would. Because it introduces modern Japan in a very unique way.
Yes, if they are interested in Japan and want to know about the problems that the nation faces and has faced post-Mishima Yukio's coup attempt in 1970.

Yes! Having no experience with Japanese literature, this course served as an excellent introduction to recent Japanese literature. The readings were among the best that Ive had since my time at Yale. This course has inspired me to pursue reading more Japanese literature. The professor is great, he really cares about the class and students.
Yes if you like reading literature. Its pretty low-commitment and most of the work comes from reading a book each week. The works and discussions are pretty insightful and the prof is super chill.

I would recommend this course to anyone. It's a wonderful way to engage with recent Japanese history as well as improve your close reading and analysis skills. The free discussion style of class allowed for a broad range of conversation.

Hard question to answer. The workload is totally reasonable, and the 10-page final paper is doable and, if you find an interesting topic, rewarding. Some books on the syllabus need to be removed--I regretted spending my time reading "The Housekeeper and the Professor" and "Territory of Light," for example. Not just because these books aren't very interesting, but also I don't think these books offer a broad ground for analysis, either. Prof. is very knowledgeable, but I wish the discussion can be a bit more guided, with more lecturing on Japan's history, culture, and literary devices and theory. There was one class we spent a bit too much time talking about baseball mentioned in a pop fiction. I like baseball, but I'd prefer not to discuss it in a literature class.

Yes! Professor Goddard is so kind and knowledgeable and will really give his time and energies to giving you resources on Japanese lit/criticism/research if you ask. The class was pretty laid back and discussions weren't stressful. Plus the reading material is some of the most fun and engaging I've read at Yale yet. If you're an English or Comp Lit or Literature major, this is a great choice of a class because it's a totally different style of literature but taught in English (and can count for your major if necessary, I think). The assignments were graded pretty casually and weren't hard at all to complete.
Yes, an excellent course

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Accompanied with a weekly Japansese section where students study the original text.
Discussion with TF.
